data.title: Celebrities Graves
data.meta_description: Hollywood Forever. John Carlyle appeared in Spirit of St Louis, Mike Hammer, and Paper Dolls among other roles. He also wrote Under the Rainbow: An
data.text:
Pentaxian

Join Date: Dec 2006

Location: So California

Photos: Gallery

Posts: 16,486

Original Poster

Hollywood Forever.

John Carlyle appeared in Spirit of St Louis, Mike Hammer, and Paper Dolls among other roles. He also wrote Under the Rainbow: An Intimate Memoir of Judy Garland, Rock Hudson and My Life in Old Hollywood.

Ruth Renick was a stage and film actress through the late 30s, appearing in The Mollycoddle, What'a A Life Worth?, The Men of Zanzibar, and Cannonball Express.

Edward LeSaint acted in over 250 films including Huckleberry Finn, Horse Feathers, Reefer Madness and Modern Times. He also directed 130 silent films and wrote 8 screenplays.

Last edited by SpecialK; 11-05-2014 at 04:06 PM.

Pentaxian

Join Date: Dec 2006

Location: So California

Photos: Gallery

Posts: 16,486

Original Poster

Holy Cross.

Argentina Brunetti was a stage actress, appeared in It's a Wonderful Life, and TVs Everybody Loves Raymond, wrote for and performed on radio, hosted the blog Argentina Brunetti's Hollywood Stories, and wrote music, articles and books.

Pedro Gonzalez Gonzalez toured as a child in the family act Las Perlitas, was a stand up comedian after WWII, appeared on You Bet Your Life with Groucho Max, and was in the John Wayne movies Rio Bravo, The High and the Mighty, and Hellfighters.

Jose Gonzalez Gonzalez acted in The Naked Gun 2 1/2, but he is best known for recurring roles in TV Westerns such as The Cisco Kid, Bonanza, Wagon Train, The Big Valley and The Rifleman.

Last edited by SpecialK; 11-05-2014 at 04:09 PM.

Pentaxian

Join Date: Dec 2006

Location: So California

Photos: Gallery

Posts: 16,486

Original Poster

Home of Peace.

Ivan Behrendt Kahn was an amateur boxer, a member of the California Coast Artillery in WWI, and a director who started the Kahn's Kid Komedies in the 20s.

Kahn co-wrote 1940's Star Dust, starring Linda Darnell and John Payne. He was a talent scout for Daryl F Zanuck from 1938 until his death.

Jack Skirball was a rabbi in the 20s and early 30s before getting into movie producing. As manager of Education Films he produced the first movie showing the actual birth of a baby. His credits include Hitchcock's Saboteur, and Shadow of A Doubt.

He invested wisely in the Vacation Village near San Diego, and later funded LA's Skirball Cultural Center, and the Jack H. Skirball Middle School.

Joseph Kauffman was one of many soldiers to die in WWI. His parents sued a life insurance company which refused to pay on Joseph's policy, citing the "war clause" (no record of outcome). Later, a memorial was erected in nearby Temple City by his brother's employer - oilman Walter Temple - near Kauffman Avenue.

Last edited by SpecialK; 11-05-2014 at 04:12 PM.

Pentaxian

Join Date: Dec 2006

Location: So California

Photos: Gallery

Posts: 16,486

Original Poster

Evergreen.

James Banning, accompanied by his mechanic Thomas Allen, became America's first black aviator to fly coast-to-coast, which took 21 days because they had to raise money at each stop. He died as a passenger in an air show crash.

Joseph Robinson arrived in LA in 1873 and founded a dry goods store called the Boston Store, later becoming Robinson's and Robinson's May.

James Mackey was a catcher and manager in Negro league baseball. He had a lifetime batting avg of .322, and played in the 1947 All-Star game at age 50.

Last edited by SpecialK; 11-05-2014 at 04:14 PM.

Pentaxian

Join Date: Dec 2006

Location: So California

Photos: Gallery

Posts: 16,486

Original Poster

Holy Cross.

Hobart Cavanaugh acted in I Cover the Waterfront, Mary Stevens MD, A Midsummer Night's Dream, Captain Blood, Wife vs Secretary, and A Letter to Three Wives.

Polly Ann Young acted opposite John Wayne in The Man from Utah, and with Bela Lugosi in Invisible Ghost. Sister of actresses Loretta Young and Sally Blane.

James Monaco was a composer with oscar nominations for Only Forever from Rhythm on the River, We Mustn't Say Goodbye from Stage Door Canteen, I'm Making Believe from Sweet and Lowdown, and I Can't Begin to Tell You from The Dolly Sisters.

Last edited by SpecialK; 11-05-2014 at 04:17 PM.

Pentaxian

Join Date: Dec 2006

Location: So California

Photos: Gallery

Posts: 16,486

Original Poster

Hollywood Forever.

Roscoe Karns was a supporting actor in It Happened One Night , His Girl Friday, Woman of the Year, and starred in TVs Rocky King, Detective.

Leah Baird acted in many silent movies, including opposite Douglas Fairbanks. Her last bit appearances were in Around the World in Eighty Days, and A Hard Man both 1957. She also wrote several screenplays.

Anne Bauchens edited every DeMille film from 1915's We Can't Have Everything and ending with The Ten Commandments 38 years later. She was nominated for four Oscars and won for North West Mounted Police.

Last edited by SpecialK; 11-05-2014 at 04:19 PM.

Pentaxian

Join Date: Dec 2006

Location: So California

Photos: Gallery

Posts: 16,486

Original Poster

Evergreen.

Frank Braxton was one of the first black animators, working at Warner Bros, and later directing The Bullwinkle Show, Mr. Magoo, George of the Jungle, and Cap'n Crunch commercials.

Bridget Mason was a former slave who worked as a nurse, and donated land for the First AME church. She fed and sheltered the poor, visited prisoners, founded a traveler's aid center, and an elementary school for black children.

James K Sturgeon earned The Medal of Honor during the Civil War for heroism June 15, 1864 at Kenesaw Mountain, GA.

Last edited by SpecialK; 11-05-2014 at 06:27 PM.

Pentaxian

Join Date: Dec 2006

Location: So California

Photos: Gallery

Posts: 16,486

Original Poster

Hollywood Forever.

Byron Palmer acted and sang in the hit Broadway musical Where's Charley?, co-starred in Man in the Attic and on TVs This Is Your Music, and Bride and Groom, repeated on Perry Mason, and emceed beauty pageants.

Elmer Brendel stared in vaudeville with his wife, Flo. As The Synthetic Swede with a fractured accent, from 1929-31, he was in nearly all Fox features, usually as a comic. He was in the Oscar nominated 2-reeler Blitz Kiss in 1941.

Giacomo Spadoni was an operatic conductor, and coach for Enrico Caruso and Mario Lanza.

Last edited by SpecialK; 11-05-2014 at 04:21 PM.

Marilyn Monroe 'suicide'

Whoever wrote this obit for Marilyn Monroe clearly doesn't know that her death

was immediately up for speculation on Aug 5 1962 and i may have the DOD incorrect by a day.

Years of forenci science have all but said her death was murder.

to claim she took her life without a cloud of proof gives one pause as to why

a statement like this would still be written in 2013.

but i would like to thank this person...for its been quite sometime

since i have had the opportuntiy to be so highly embarrassed for them, for clearly

they don't have the common sense to be embarrassed for themself.

Pentaxian

Location: So California

Photos: Gallery

Original Poster

Hollywood Forever.

Joseph Cawthorn acted in Gold Diggers of 1935, and The Great Ziegfeld. He was married to actress Queenie Vassar who appeared late in her career in A Primrose Path.

Fred Warren and his wife appeared in vaudeville, then he appeared in 66 films. Actor Rudy Valentino was married in his backyard.

Harry Lachman was a magazine artist and painter, then directed 45 movies including George White's Scandals, Charlie Chan at the Circus, They Came by Night, and The Loves of Edgar Allan Poe.

Last edited by SpecialK; 11-05-2014 at 04:25 PM.

Pentaxian

Join Date: Dec 2006

Location: So California

Photos: Gallery

Posts: 16,486

Original Poster

Hollywood Forever.

Byron Stevens was the brother of Ruby Stevens AKA actress Barbara Stanwyck, and played extras in films for 25 years.

George Berkeley acted in The Adventures of Rin Tin Tin, Captain Midnite, The Left-Handed Gun, Daniel Boone, Glass Houses, and Life Stinks.

Edward Connelly was a newpaper reporter before acting on stage and in silent films, notably The Four Horsemen of the Apocalypse, The Prisoner of Zenda, and Scaramouche. The clock tower at Hollywood Forever was dedicated in his memory in 1930.

Last edited by SpecialK; 11-05-2014 at 06:34 PM.

Pentaxian

Join Date: Dec 2006

Location: So California

Photos: Gallery

Posts: 16,486

Original Poster

Holy Cross.

Marguerite Chapman was a telephone operator, then model, then actress in the 12-part serial Spy Smasher, and The Seven Year Itch. In WWII she sold War Bonds and helped at the Hollywood Canteen.

George Folsey was a cinematographer with 11 oscar nominations including Meet Me In St Louis, Seven Brides For Seven Brothers, and The Balcony. Won an Emmy for Here's Peggy Fleming.

Horace McNally was a lawyer, then actor, whose career improved after changing his name to Stephen. Mostly played bad guys, notably in Johnny Belinda, and Winchester 73. Starred in TVs Target: The Corruptors.

Last edited by SpecialK; 11-05-2014 at 06:36 PM.

Pentaxian

Join Date: Dec 2006

Location: So California

Photos: Gallery

Posts: 16,486

Original Poster

Holy Cross.

James Flavin dropped out of West Point, drove a taxi, starred in his first acting role in the serial Airmail Mystery, appeared as a sheriff on Sky King, and as Eisenhower in Francis Gary Powers: The True Story of the U-2 Spy Incident.

Dennis Day was a singer and appeared on Jack Benny's radio show where he also did impersonations of Ronald Colman, Jimmy Durante and James Stewart. Though he stayed with Benny for years, Day had his own radio and TV shows. Star on the Walk of Fame.

Gaston Glass acted in 100 roles through the early 40s, and was later a production manager on 12 O'Clock High, Lost In Space, Daniel Boone, and Voyage to the Bottom of the Sea.

Last edited by SpecialK; 11-05-2014 at 06:38 PM.

Pentaxian

Join Date: Dec 2006

Location: So California

Photos: Gallery

Posts: 16,486

Original Poster

Oakwood, Chatsworth.

Henry Victor was the circus strongman in 1932's Freaks, and the dumb Gestapo Captain Schultz in To Be or Not to Be.

Russell Hayden was a western performer and helped develop Pioneertown in Southern California. He first worked as a camera assistant, then acted in many Hopalong Cassidy films as cowboy Lucky Jenkins.

Al Jennings was a short but big-talking cowboy, lawyer, poor gunslinger, ineffective train robber, jailbird, evangelist, failed politician, author, and actor in silent westerns. Dan Duryea played him in 1951's Al Jennings of Oklahoma.

Last edited by SpecialK; 11-05-2014 at 06:43 PM.
